We formulated two predictive models to generate estimates of growth for the ith cluster C i , which we denote respectively as the null model and the weighted model. The null model requires less information by postulating that each cluster is expected to grow in proportion to its current size, prior to the addition of new cases, as a fraction of the entire population of known cases. For example, a cluster that comprises half of all known cases is predicted to accumulate half of new cases that are adjacent to any cluster. There are two advantages to using individual-level weights in Equation (2) rather than cluster-level weights: first, individual-level weights are independent of clustering thresholds, so it is sufficient to calculate weights one time only; second, individual-level weights confer a greater degree of precision for measuring effects on edge densities that would become averaged out in clusters.
